prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. Compute $10^{-1}\pmod{1001}$. Express your answer as a residue from $0$ to $1000$, inclusive.
solution:
Notice that $1001=10\cdot 100+1$. Therefore, $$10\cdot 100\equiv -1 \pmod{1001},$$which implies that $$10\cdot -100\equiv 1\pmod{1001}.$$The inverse of $10\pmod{1001}$ is $-100$, but we need an answer in the interval from $0$ to $1000$. The equivalent residue in this interval is $-100+1001 = \boxed{901}$.

We can check our answer: $10\cdot 901 = 9010 = 9(1001)+1 \equiv 1\pmod{1001}$, so $901$ is indeed the inverse of $10\pmod{1001}$.
gpt_response:
We can rewrite $10^{-1}\pmod{1001}$ as the solution to the congruence $10x \equiv 1 \pmod{1001}$. This is equivalent to finding the modular multiplicative inverse of $10$ modulo $1001$. 

Since $10$ and $1001$ are relatively prime, we know that $10$ has a modular multiplicative inverse modulo $1001$. To find this inverse, we can use the extended Euclidean algorithm. 

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Step} & \text{Equation} & q & \text{Modifications} \\
\hline
0 & 1001 = 10 \cdot 100 + 1 & & \\
1 & 10 = 1 \cdot 10 + 0 & 100 & \\
2 & 1 = 100 - 1 \cdot 10 & 10 & \text{Substitute in equation 0} \\
3 & 1 = 100 - 1 \cdot (1001 - 10 \cdot 100) & -1 & \text{Substitute in equation 1} \\
4 & 1 = 100 \cdot 1001 + (-1) \cdot 10 & & \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

From the extended Euclidean algorithm, we have found that $1 = 100 \cdot 1001 - 10$. Therefore, the modular multiplicative inverse of $10$ modulo $1001$ is $-10$, or $991$. 

Thus, $10^{-1} \equiv 991 \pmod{1001}$. The residue of $991$ from $0$ to $1000$ is $\boxed{991}$.
